Athletic elections held
Wednesday resulted in the naming
of Clifford Siverd and Woodward
White to the captaincies of the
1934-35 basketball and swimming
teams, respectively.
It was also announced that Stewart Collenberg and Robert Abrams
had been elected to the managerial
Positions in these sports.
Recommend Lettermen

At the meeting attended by members of the swimming squad, Coach
Waldo Hambleton and retiring
Captain Ed Sadtler recommended
the following performers as worthy
recipients of the varsity "H": Ed
adtler, Woody White, and Frank
Levi.
The names of John Magill, Lou
Adler, Bill McConnell, and Dan
Wiener were proposed for minor
The recommending of
letters.
Wiener is of especial significance,
since he is only a freshman and
chose to compete with the firstyear men rather than the varsity
this season. It was pointed out,
however, that his performances
Were of varsity calibre and that he
undoubtedly merited the award.
Siverd Stars

A member of the 'first-string
basketball line-up for two years,
Siverd came into particular prominence during the past campaign
as the result of his scintillating play
at forward. He was named on the
second All-Maryland team by nuinerous State coaches and authorities. Cliff is also a ranking member of the tennis team.
For White also, the past season
Marked his second of active participation in swimming. -He is the
Present co-holder of the South Atlantic 100-yard title.
During the
Year he tied the Hopkins record for
the same distance by finishing in the
time of 57.3 seconds.

"Brain Mechanisms Underlying Emotional Behavior"
Is Topic Of Discussion
"Brain Mechanisms Underlying
Emotional Behavior" was the subject discussed by Dr. Philip Bard
at a meeting of the Johns Hopkins
chapter of the society of the Sigma Xi, held last Monday evening
in the auditorium of the School of
Hygiene.
Dr. Bard, newly appointed professor and head of the department
of physiology in the. Hopkins Medical School showed by demonstrations on a cat the independence of
emotional action from actual emotional feeling, and showed that, the
cortex of the brain is the control
center that connects intelligently
feeling and reaction.
Research Work

Dr. Bard has taught physiology
at Princeton and Harvard Universities, where he did numerous
researches on the neural basis of
emotional reactions, control of the
sympathetic
nervous system,
functions of the hypothalamus,
and nervous and humoral control
of the heart rate.
The Hopkins chapter of the
Sigma Xi, was chartered by the
national organization in 1924. At
present its president is Dr.'W. W.
Cort, and M. W. Pullen its secretary.
The Society of the Sigma Xi
was founded at Cornell University in 1886, and has at present
about 60 chapters. Its aim is the
fostering of scientific research
work.

Spring Geology Trip
Scheduled For April25
Due to the unusual weather conditions of spring vacations
and to the lack of time available
this year for adequate preparation,
the annual spring geology field trip
will be scheduled for April 25, 26,
27, 28, it has been announced by
Dr. Mark Secrist, professor of undergraduate geology.
For many years this feature of
the geology courSe has taken students up through Western Maryland and West Virginia during the
spring vacation.

Praising the stand against war
taken by Maryland students at the
recent Conference on War and the
Student held here under the auspices of Hopkins and Goucher College Liberal Clubs, the Baltimore
Preachers' Association of the
Methodist Episcopal Church, at a
meeting on 'March 8, adopted a
resolution commending the student
attitude.
The resolution reads as follows:
"In view of the fact that our General Conference in its last session
said: 'We hold that our country is
benefited by having as citizens those
who unswervingly follow the dictates of their consciences', and has
further stated: 'We believe it to be
the duty of the Churches to give
moral support to those individuals
who hold conscientious scruples
against participation in military
service', we desire to commend the
students who, in a recent meeting
at Johns Hopkins University in
loyalty to their convictions, signed
the declaration that 'under no circumstances will we support any
war entered into by the Government
of the United States.'"
Resolved At Conference

This resolution is the latest development arising from the antiwar declaration adopted as an outcome of the Intercollegiate Conference held in Levering Hall on
March 2 and 3.
The student position was earlier
criticized by. Caesar Aeillo, commander, Maryland district of the
American Legion; Major-General
Paul B. Malone, commander of the
Third Corps Area; Dr. Arthur B.
Kinsolving of Old St. Paul's
Church, and other prominent citizens. Echoes of the Conference
were alsd heard on the campus of
the University of Maryland where
The Diamondback, a student publication, promptly denied that that
institution has a Liberal Club, and
stated that, contrary to reports in
the Sun, Maryland students who
attended the conclave were not authorized to represent the University.

Today In Gilman, 305
Professor Thomas S. Barclay,
of Leland Stanford University,
will give a lecture on "Champ
Clark" at 11.30 in Gilman 305 today.
Professor Barclay has spent the
past week in Washington collecting material for a biography of
Members of the
Speaker Clark.
staffs and graduate students in the
departments of political science,
history, and economics are invited.
Is Native Of St. Louis
A native of St. Louis, Dr. Barclay obtained his A.B. and M. A.
degrees at the University of Missouri. At Missouri Dr. Barclay belonged to the Beta Theta Pi Fraternity and Phi Beta Kappa. After
receiving his M.A. degree, Dr.
Barclay taught, as an instructor in
the political science department.
In 1920 he became assistant professor. Two years later, he was
made associate professor in the political science department. After
receiving his Ph.D. from Columbia, Dr. Barclay, returned to Stanford, and was given a full professorship in 1927.

lecture tour of the nation furthering the cause of good will among
the bickering sects.
Introduced by Edward Sadtler,
Rev. Clinchy proceeded to reveal
the purpose of his past pilgrimage. He likened the contesting
religions to the fingers on one's
hand. It is necessary for them to
remain separate by their very nature; but, he continued, when the
time comes, it will be also requisite for those fingers to fold together to form a fist, which will
be forcefully effective for a common end.

Well-Known Teacher

One of the leading political scientists in the country, Professor
Barclay is a member of the executive council of the American Political Science Association, and is
an active participant in the American Political Science Academf.
Although his major interest is
political science, the speaker is also
well known in law circles. A scholar in public law at Columbia, 192021, he obtained the foundation for
his brilliant work in the international peace negotiations at Paris in
1919.
Guest Of Dr. Hart

He is perhaps best known for his
diverse articles, being a contributor
to the American Political Science
Review, the National Municipal Refiezez, the California Law Review,
and the Missouri History Review.
Dr. Barclay will spend the week
with Dr. Hart and will be his guest
of honor at a stag dinner to be held
at the Baltimore Country Club tonight.

Lazaron Follows

Rev. Clinchy observed that,
judging from the experience of
history, the group which has the
most number of adherents is most
likely to express a cruel intolerance toward the other groups. But
in America, he said, this is entirely contrary to that tolerance
which is generally considered the
spirit of the nation.
In this city, Rabbi Lazaron asserted, there are forty-five thousand
familis in digtress, and the municipal relief will soon be abandoned. With a seething unrest evident all over the country, there
must be a better understanding
among the religious, groups, he
continued, else mild dislikes there
will break out out into hatreds.
Cause Given

The areas of such friction are
due for the most part, to ignorance. As testimony of this, Rabbi
Lazaron pointed to the widespread fear of Catholic domination and to the common belief
that Jews control the financial
powers of America.
Questions and points-of-view
from the floor followed. Some of
the ideas then advanced are as
follows: there is prejudice against
the Jews because they are associated with radical movements,
ambitious and over-forward, and
regarded as inferior; prejudice is
inculcated in the education of
Christians; and lastly, many
agreed that, though they disliked
Jews as a race, still they thought
highly of them as individuals and
friends.

Giving The Women A Break
We quite agree with the student who opined that
the College for Teachers owes THE NEWS-LETTER a
vote of thanks for pointing to its penury in the way
of pulchritude. He added that prior to reading the
article he didn't even know a College for Teachers
existed at Homewood!

Give The Women A Break
An article concerning Goucher College appearing
elsewhere on this page impresses upon us the utter
dearth of social relations between that institution and
the Hopkins. An issue of the Jay last year revealed
but six marriages consummated during the last ten
years. Shades of Margaret Sanger!

Friday, March 16, 1934

Eternal Freshmen .
Several incidents which occurred during the week
lead us to believe that it might be well for the University to establish two new courses for the benefit
of many of its undergraduate students. And since
we suggest the idea, we take the liberty to propose the
following titles as suitable for these curricula: "The
Art of Growing Up" and "An Appreciation for the
Rights of Others". Neither course would find itself
lacking in disciples, and, in the face of the events
alluded to, both would react, immeasurably to the
benefit of the Hopkins.
Incident Number 1, which indicated prospective
members for both courses, directly concerns the minor
fire which broke out in the Dorms on Wednesday.
The authorities, believing themselves prepared for
such an emergency, quickly and confidently sought
the fire extinguishers. Imagine their consternation
and anger to find that some of the extinguishers had
been removed and concealed by some just-too-clever,
ducky-wucicy students, and that the few which resided in their proper places had been rendered ineffective by these same oh-so-cunning individuals,
who had emptied them of their original contents and
refilled them with water. As a result, many innocent
residents saw damage done to their property before
the blaze could be put out.
This is not the first instance of such infantile
conduct emanating from the Dorms; on the contrary,
it is merely a typical example of the unruly behavior
which predominates at times. It wouldn't be so bad
if the instigators were the ones who felt the effect
of their pranks, but unfortunately such is not the
case. Those in charge have repeatedly attempted to
curb this mild form of vandalism by warnings of
fines and the like, but to no avail. It appears as if
children must play.
Incident Number 2, though less general in character, is nevertheless fraught with more serious consequences. According to information received from
a most reliable source, three members of the CWA
crew, while working alongside the road which runs
past Latrobe and Maryland Halls, have been hit and
badly shaken up by student-driven machines this
week.
Each accident was declared to have been the
resuit of gross carelessness on the part of the drivers,
who were evidently intent upon getting nowhere in
a hurry. In one case the injured individual was forced
to forego his work for several days. It is our opinion that this group can be cured by a reproach, or, at the
most, a reprimand. So we refuse them admittance
to the above-delineated courses and merely urge:
Kindly stop, look, and listen.

Wisdom From Olympus
Those two august bodies in whose hands the fate
campus apparently rests (it seems so superthe
of
fluous to name them as the Student Council and the
Student Activities Council) certainly slipped up
when they mutually published their reasons for the
maintenance of compulsory attendance on the part of
freshmen and sophomores at the weekly assemblies.
Their statement, to the effect that "the assembly
is the only unifying medium left between the underclasses, and the only means by which activities can
publicize themselves", was very poorly composed, to
say the least.
It's hard to imagine any group gathering that is As
passive and non-conducive to fraternizing as the asassembly. Students enter usually in groups of two
or three, sit down apparently oblivious of their own
classmates, not to mention the members of the other
class, and, after the signal for dismissal is given,
usually walk out in the same company. Certainly not
much furtherance of unity between the two classes is
accomplished by the procedure.
As for the publicizing of activities, we really
can't confess to a feeling of intensified interest in the
Musical Club after having heard its twenty-minute
program at an assembly held" last month. Compelling
students to attend for, this alone, when they are to
hear the very same selections the following evening,
smacks of outright tyranny. By and large, the other
organizations put in their appearance at the annual
activities assembly and then fade from the so-called
"publicizing picture."

Annie Oakley, daughter-in-law of famous Buffalo Bill
and a confessed drug addict, was sentenced for stealing. News
items played up the story and said that she stole to get
money with which to buy drugs—though she had made no
statement to that effect. Shortly after 50 newspapers were
sued for libel by Annie. She won 48 of the cases and
collected damages ranging from $500 to $27,500.

Students in the department of geology at the
Pacific College will make a trip to the Mohave desert
region and Death Valley during spring vacation to
study soil and rock formation. ,
Huron College, situated in London, Ontario, is
probably the smallest college in existence today. It
carries a total enrollment of twenty students and five
faculty members.

Journalism Group
Commends Staff
Of News-Letter
"The campus paper, THE NEWSLETTER will continue to be improved under the direction of the
newly - elected editor - in - chief,
Stanley Blumberg," it was said
yesterday by Hyman Levin, president of the Pi Delta Epsilon,
national honorary college journalism fraternity.
"Norman Heaney,_who just retired deserves great credit for the
splendid, vigorous editorial policy he carried through with excellent results. He did a good job
and won for THE NEWS-LETTER at
the fall meeting of the Intercollegiate Newspaper Association
third place in editorials in a competition among 26 leading papers
in the Middle Atlantic States.
"Though I cannot at this time
-say anything about Blumberg's
editorial policy, I do say without
any fear of contradiction that TRE
NEWS-LETTER, under his editorship, will become among the first
five best, from the make-up and
typographic standpoint. His initial issue this Tuesday is a good
enough bit of evidence."

Glen Harmeson, newly appointed
head coach of Lehigh University's football team had his first
chance to view his prospects this
week, when the Brown and White
aspirants turned out for their annual spring football practice.
Led by Charles ("Whitey")
Ock, captain-elect, the fifty candidates who were present spent
most of the drills in exercises.
A large group of letter men were
present.
At the conclusion of the first
practice Coach Harmeson addressed his men, explaining that
the Notre Dame system of play
would be taught, in preference to
the wmgback formations of the
Warner system, used in the past
few years at Lehigh.

New Rules

In addition to filling up the gaps
left by these losses the coaching
staff is confronted with the task
of teaching the new rules to their
players. An additional man must
be kept in the defense zone at all
times and the field has been lengthened ten yards again.
A few shifts in the line-up may
prove advantageous in plugging up
the gaps left by the loss of veterans. The position of center is well
cared for, since both Beeler and
Packard are eligible this year..
To add to this list there will be
many reserves from last year and
freshmen. Lou
several
Reuling, a sophomore goalie, and
Reub Pasarew, a defense man, are
back again, while Bob Levi, one of
the best attackmen in the high
school ranks last year, will also be
out for the team.

Members of last year's varsity
tennis team and all new candidates are requested to attend a
special organization meeting, to
be held today at 12.30, Latrobe,
120.
The purpose of the meeting is
to discuss plans for the annual
spring tournament, which is held
to test the new candidates. All
candidates must register at this
meeting.

The Hopkins grapplers were
defeated by the local Y. M. C. A.
Tuesday night by a score of 26-0.
Hartman and Gelber, 135 and 125
pound classes, were the only two
Jays who were not defeated by
falls.
Williamson of the Y. M. C. A.
gained the decision over Gelber
while Eareckson defeated Hartman. Andes of the Y. M.' C. A.,
gained a fall over E. Miller, manager of the Jays, in the 125-pound
class. Stoler, McDaniels, and
Davies also represented Hopkins.
The Jays will continue their
training as they plan to enter the
South Atlantics.

Positions in these sports.

"Brain Mechanisms Underlying Emotional Behavior"
Is Topic Of Discussion
"Brain Mechanisms Underlying
Emotional Behavior" was the subject discussed by Dr. Philip Bard
at a meeting of the Johns Hopkins
chapter of the society of the Sigma Xi, held last Monday evening
in the auditorium of the School of
Hygiene.
Dr. Bard, newly appointed professor and head of the department
of physiology in the. Hopkins Medical School showed by demonstrations on a cat the independence of
emotional action from actual emotional feeling, and showed that, the
cortex of the brain is the control
center that connects intelligently
feeling and reaction.
Research Work

Dr. Bard has taught physiology
at Princeton and Harvard Universities, where he did numerous
researches on the neural basis of

nervous system,

national organization in 1924. At

Cort, and M. W. Pullen its secretary.

was founded at Cornell University in 1886, and has at present
about 60 chapters. Its aim is the
fostering of scientific research
work.

Spring Geology Trip
Scheduled For April25
Due to the unusual weather conditions of spring vacations
and to the lack of time available
this year for adequate preparation,
the annual spring geology field trip
will be scheduled for April 25, 26,
27, 28, it has been announced by
Dr. Mark Secrist, professor of undergraduate geology.
For many years this feature of
the geology courSe has taken students up through Western Maryland and West Virginia during the
spring vacation.

Praising the stand against war
taken by Maryland students at the
recent Conference on War and the
Student held here under the auspices of Hopkins and Goucher College Liberal Clubs, the Baltimore
Preachers' Association of the
Methodist Episcopal Church, at a
meeting on 'March 8, adopted a
resolution commending the student
attitude.
The resolution reads as follows:
"In view of the fact that our General Conference in its last session
said: 'We hold that our country is
benefited by having as citizens those
who unswervingly follow the dictates of their consciences', and has
further stated: 'We believe it to be
the duty of the Churches to give
moral support to those individuals
who hold conscientious scruples
against participation in military
service', we desire to commend the
students who, in a recent meeting
at Johns Hopkins University in
loyalty to their convictions, signed
the declaration that 'under no circumstances will we support any
war entered into by the Government
of the United States.'"
Resolved At Conference

This resolution is the latest development arising from the antiwar declaration adopted as an outcome of the Intercollegiate Conference held in Levering Hall on
March 2 and 3.
The student position was earlier
criticized by. Caesar Aeillo, commander, Maryland district of the
American Legion; Major-General
Paul B. Malone, commander of the
Third Corps Area; Dr. Arthur B.
Kinsolving of Old St. Paul's
Church, and other prominent citizens. Echoes of the Conference
were alsd heard on the campus of
the University of Maryland where
The Diamondback, a student publication, promptly denied that that
institution has a Liberal Club, and
stated that, contrary to reports in
the Sun, Maryland students who
attended the conclave were not authorized to represent the University.

Today In Gilman, 305
Professor Thomas S. Barclay,
of Leland Stanford University,
will give a lecture on "Champ
Clark" at 11.30 in Gilman 305 today.
Professor Barclay has spent the
past week in Washington collecting material for a biography of
Members of the

Is Native Of St. Louis
A native of St. Louis, Dr. Barclay obtained his A.B. and M. A.
degrees at the University of Missouri. At Missouri Dr. Barclay belonged to the Beta Theta Pi Fraternity and Phi Beta Kappa. After
receiving his M.A. degree, Dr.
Barclay taught, as an instructor in
the political science department.
In 1920 he became assistant professor. Two years later, he was
made associate professor in the political science department. After
receiving his Ph.D. from Columbia, Dr. Barclay, returned to Stanford, and was given a full professorship in 1927.

lecture tour of the nation furthering the cause of good will among
the bickering sects.
Introduced by Edward Sadtler,
Rev. Clinchy proceeded to reveal
the purpose of his past pilgrimage. He likened the contesting
religions to the fingers on one's
hand. It is necessary for them to
remain separate by their very nature; but, he continued, when the
time comes, it will be also requisite for those fingers to fold together to form a fist, which will
be forcefully effective for a common end.

Well-Known Teacher

One of the leading political scientists in the country, Professor
Barclay is a member of the executive council of the American Political Science Association, and is
an active participant in the American Political Science Academf.
Although his major interest is
political science, the speaker is also
well known in law circles. A scholar in public law at Columbia, 192021, he obtained the foundation for
his brilliant work in the international peace negotiations at Paris in
1919.
Guest Of Dr. Hart

He is perhaps best known for his
diverse articles, being a contributor
to the American Political Science
Review, the National Municipal Refiezez, the California Law Review,
and the Missouri History Review.
Dr. Barclay will spend the week
with Dr. Hart and will be his guest
of honor at a stag dinner to be held
at the Baltimore Country Club tonight.

Lazaron Follows

Rev. Clinchy observed that,
judging from the experience of
history, the group which has the
most number of adherents is most
likely to express a cruel intolerance toward the other groups. But
in America, he said, this is entirely contrary to that tolerance
which is generally considered the
spirit of the nation.
In this city, Rabbi Lazaron asserted, there are forty-five thousand
familis in digtress, and the municipal relief will soon be abandoned. With a seething unrest evident all over the country, there
must be a better understanding
among the religious, groups, he
continued, else mild dislikes there
will break out out into hatreds.
Cause Given

The areas of such friction are
due for the most part, to ignorance. As testimony of this, Rabbi
Lazaron pointed to the widespread fear of Catholic domination and to the common belief
that Jews control the financial
powers of America.
Questions and points-of-view
from the floor followed. Some of
the ideas then advanced are as
follows: there is prejudice against
the Jews because they are associated with radical movements,
ambitious and over-forward, and
regarded as inferior; prejudice is
inculcated in the education of
Christians; and lastly, many
agreed that, though they disliked
Jews as a race, still they thought
highly of them as individuals and
friends.

Friday, March 16, 1934

Eternal Freshmen .
Several incidents which occurred during the week
lead us to believe that it might be well for the University to establish two new courses for the benefit
of many of its undergraduate students. And since
we suggest the idea, we take the liberty to propose the
following titles as suitable for these curricula: "The
Art of Growing Up" and "An Appreciation for the
Rights of Others". Neither course would find itself
lacking in disciples, and, in the face of the events
alluded to, both would react, immeasurably to the
benefit of the Hopkins.
Incident Number 1, which indicated prospective
members for both courses, directly concerns the minor
fire which broke out in the Dorms on Wednesday.
The authorities, believing themselves prepared for
such an emergency, quickly and confidently sought
the fire extinguishers. Imagine their consternation
and anger to find that some of the extinguishers had
been removed and concealed by some just-too-clever,
ducky-wucicy students, and that the few which resided in their proper places had been rendered ineffective by these same oh-so-cunning individuals,
who had emptied them of their original contents and
refilled them with water. As a result, many innocent
residents saw damage done to their property before
the blaze could be put out.
This is not the first instance of such infantile
conduct emanating from the Dorms; on the contrary,
it is merely a typical example of the unruly behavior
which predominates at times. It wouldn't be so bad
if the instigators were the ones who felt the effect
of their pranks, but unfortunately such is not the
case. Those in charge have repeatedly attempted to
curb this mild form of vandalism by warnings of
fines and the like, but to no avail. It appears as if
children must play.
Incident Number 2, though less general in character, is nevertheless fraught with more serious consequences. According to information received from
a most reliable source, three members of the CWA
crew, while working alongside the road which runs
past Latrobe and Maryland Halls, have been hit and
badly shaken up by student-driven machines this
week.
Each accident was declared to have been the
resuit of gross carelessness on the part of the drivers,
who were evidently intent upon getting nowhere in
a hurry. In one case the injured individual was forced
to forego his work for several days. It is our opinion that this group can be cured by a reproach, or, at the
most, a reprimand. So we refuse them admittance
to the above-delineated courses and merely urge:
Kindly stop, look, and listen.

Wisdom From Olympus
Those two august bodies in whose hands the fate
campus apparently rests (it seems so superthe
of
fluous to name them as the Student Council and the
Student Activities Council) certainly slipped up
when they mutually published their reasons for the
maintenance of compulsory attendance on the part of
freshmen and sophomores at the weekly assemblies.
Their statement, to the effect that "the assembly
is the only unifying medium left between the underclasses, and the only means by which activities can
publicize themselves", was very poorly composed, to
say the least.
It's hard to imagine any group gathering that is As
passive and non-conducive to fraternizing as the asassembly. Students enter usually in groups of two
or three, sit down apparently oblivious of their own
classmates, not to mention the members of the other
class, and, after the signal for dismissal is given,
usually walk out in the same company. Certainly not
much furtherance of unity between the two classes is
accomplished by the procedure.
As for the publicizing of activities, we really
can't confess to a feeling of intensified interest in the
Musical Club after having heard its twenty-minute
program at an assembly held" last month. Compelling
students to attend for, this alone, when they are to
hear the very same selections the following evening,
smacks of outright tyranny. By and large, the other
organizations put in their appearance at the annual
activities assembly and then fade from the so-called
"publicizing picture."
Perhaps the Councils might have fared better in

Annie Oakley, daughter-in-law of famous Buffalo Bill
and a confessed drug addict, was sentenced for stealing. News
items played up the story and said that she stole to get
money with which to buy drugs—though she had made no
statement to that effect. Shortly after 50 newspapers were
sued for libel by Annie. She won 48 of the cases and
collected damages ranging from $500 to $27,500.

Journalism Group
Commends Staff
Of News-Letter
"The campus paper, THE NEWSLETTER will continue to be improved under the direction of the
newly - elected editor - in - chief,
Stanley Blumberg," it was said
yesterday by Hyman Levin, president of the Pi Delta Epsilon,
national honorary college journalism fraternity.
"Norman Heaney,_who just retired deserves great credit for the
splendid, vigorous editorial policy he carried through with excellent results. He did a good job
and won for THE NEWS-LETTER at
the fall meeting of the Intercollegiate Newspaper Association
third place in editorials in a competition among 26 leading papers
in the Middle Atlantic States.
"Though I cannot at this time
-say anything about Blumberg's
editorial policy, I do say without
any fear of contradiction that TRE
NEWS-LETTER, under his editorship, will become among the first
five best, from the make-up and
typographic standpoint. His initial issue this Tuesday is a good
enough bit of evidence."

Glen Harmeson, newly appointed
head coach of Lehigh University's football team had his first
chance to view his prospects this
week, when the Brown and White
aspirants turned out for their annual spring football practice.
Led by Charles ("Whitey")
Ock, captain-elect, the fifty candidates who were present spent
most of the drills in exercises.
A large group of letter men were
present.
At the conclusion of the first
practice Coach Harmeson addressed his men, explaining that
the Notre Dame system of play
would be taught, in preference to
the wmgback formations of the
Warner system, used in the past
few years at Lehigh.

New Rules

In addition to filling up the gaps
left by these losses the coaching
staff is confronted with the task
of teaching the new rules to their
players. An additional man must
be kept in the defense zone at all
times and the field has been lengthened ten yards again.
A few shifts in the line-up may
prove advantageous in plugging up
the gaps left by the loss of veterans. The position of center is well
cared for, since both Beeler and
Packard are eligible this year..
To add to this list there will be
many reserves from last year and
freshmen. Lou
several
Reuling, a sophomore goalie, and
Reub Pasarew, a defense man, are
back again, while Bob Levi, one of
the best attackmen in the high
school ranks last year, will also be
out for the team.

Members of last year's varsity
tennis team and all new candidates are requested to attend a
special organization meeting, to
be held today at 12.30, Latrobe,
120.
The purpose of the meeting is
to discuss plans for the annual
spring tournament, which is held
to test the new candidates. All
candidates must register at this
meeting.

The Hopkins grapplers were
defeated by the local Y. M. C. A.
Tuesday night by a score of 26-0.
Hartman and Gelber, 135 and 125
pound classes, were the only two
Jays who were not defeated by
falls.
Williamson of the Y. M. C. A.
gained the decision over Gelber
while Eareckson defeated Hartman. Andes of the Y. M.' C. A.,
gained a fall over E. Miller, manager of the Jays, in the 125-pound
class. Stoler, McDaniels, and
Davies also represented Hopkins.
The Jays will continue their
training as they plan to enter the
South Atlantics.
